content.description: This route feels like a highball bouldering problem, but there are spots to add protection. It's a pumpy start, leading to the crux coming out of the roof. Great problem to top rope with its chain anchors at the top.
content.protection: Standard rack, bolted, anchors at top
content.location: Scramble up the wash at the base of lower Peacepipe Arroyo. The Roof will be an obvious feature to the right.

content.description: The crux is the beginning of the route with its boulder like moves. Once you've made it to the base of the left facing dihedral the route follows a straight line up to the hangers for anchors.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. Anchors at the top.
content.location: An old piton marks the start of the route.

content.description: Peacepipe Arroyo is a collection of small crags within the McKelligon Canyon area. This area was initially listed in the Franklin Mountain Range Guidebook (2010). The rock quality is variable with potential for loose rocks. This is an excellent place to top rope, or just get some practice placing traditional gear, as the routes in the lower section are roughly 100 feet in length and mostly easy-to-moderate in grade with scrambling access through Last Chance to set top ropes for every route.
